Graphical abstract Highlights • Nutrient-dense microgreens offer strong potential as functional superfoods. • Microgreens exhibit natural antioxidant and health-enhancing properties. • Green synthesis uses microgreens’ bioactive compounds for eco-friendly nanomaterials. • BCM • Subacute toxicity study confirmed BCM- Background Prostate cancer ranks among the most lethal malignancies affecting men globally. Conventional therapeutic approaches for this disease encounter limitations due to adverse side effects and the emergence of drug resistance, making its management challenging. Green-synthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) have emerged as an attractive alternative to address the shortcomings of existing anticancer treatments. The normal Vero E6 (ATCC® CRL-1586™) cell line stemmed from green monkeys, and the prostate carcinoma cell line (DU-145, ATCC® HTB-81™) were procured from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC). Minimum Essential Medium (MEM) produced by ATCC, along with DMSO, foetal bovine serum, trypsin, were bought from Gibco BRL (Germany). MTT, PBS, and doxorubicin were acquired from Solarbio Life Sciences Company (Beijing, China). Formalin solution, ethanol, paraffin wax, and blood collection tubes were purchased from Legacy Lab Africa LTD (Nairobi, Kenya). Reagents for biochemical and hematological analyses were supplied by the manufacturers of the respective equipment. 2.2 Biosynthesis of silver nanoparticles mediated by BCME This study used previously synthesized nanoparticles from Brassica carinata BCM 17 BCM 17 2.3 In vitro 2.3.1 Cell culture conditions Cell culture was performed in MEM (GIBCO, USA) fortified with vital components for cellular growth, which include 1 % HEPES buffer (Gold Biotechnology, USA), 7.5 % Sodium hydrogen carbonate (LOBA Chemie, India), 1 % L-Glutamine (Sigma Aldrich, USA), 10 % Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS, Sigma Aldrich, USA), 1 % Penicillin/Streptomycin (Sigma Aldrich, USA). The qRT-PCR analysis was carried out with the HOT Firepol® Evagreen® qPCR Mix Plus (ROX) 5x kit (Solis BioDyne, Estonia), using the Quant Studio™ 5 RT-qPCR system (Applied Biosystems, USA) following the manufacturer's guidelines. The animals were housed in standard cages for one week to acclimatize and were subjected to a 12-h cycle of light and darkness at room temperature. They had unlimited access to water and feed pellets. Clean-cut papers were placed on the floors of the cages to serve as bedding for the animals. The cages were cleaned up daily, and the papers were replaced with fresh ones. Ethical approval All protocols received ethical clearance from the Ethics Committee for the Use and Care of Animals at Mount Kenya University, Kenya (Ref. No. MKU/ISERC/3626). The experiments were designed to minimize animal pain and distress as much as possible, following the National Institutes of Health’s Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. 56 2.4.3 Toxicological investigations on BCM The sub-acute toxicity investigation of BCM 57 58 2.4.4 Sub-acute toxicity The subacute toxicity was investigated as per the guidelines number 407 of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), which outlines the standard protocol for a 28-day repeated-dose oral toxicity study in rodent models 59 et al 60 BCM BCM in vitro BCM 61 62 2.4.5 Clinical evaluation The animals were clinically evaluated as previously described. 62 63 37 (4) (5) 62 (4) A m o u n t o f w a t e r t a k e n ( m L ) = A W G P D ( m L ) - A W R A 24 h ( m L ) (5) A m o u n t o f f e e d c o n s u m e d ( g ) = A F G P D ( g ) - A F R A 24 h ( g ) 2.4.6 Collection of samples On day 29, following an overnight fast, animals were humanely euthanized under carbon dioxide (CO 2 64 65 61 66 67 2.4.7 Analysis of biochemical parameters Blood samples in additive-free tubes were allowed to coagulate at room temperature for 1 h prior to centrifugation (3,500 rpm, 10 min). The resulting supernatant sera were subsequently used for biochemical analysis 62 68 69 2.4.8 Analysis of haematological parameters Haematological parameters were assessed using blood collected in EDTA tubes through an automated Mindray BC-5000 haematological analyzer (Mindray Medical International Limited, Shenzhen, China). The haematological parameters investigated included key blood cell counts, erythrocyte indices, and platelet indices. 64 37 59 2.4.9 Macroscopic assessment and organ relative weights Post-euthanasia, all rats underwent a macroscopic pathological investigation, encompassing an evaluation of the exterior surface, internal organs, and all orifices, as well as a record of any evident pathological changes. Results were then expressed as mean ± SD. Statistical comparisons between the different groups were performed using one-way ANOVA, followed by Dunnett's/Turkey’s post hoc test, as well as t-tests. It relies on the aptitude of succinate dehydrogenase, a mitochondrial enzyme, to convert tetrazolium salt (MTT) in metabolically active cells into purple formazan crystals. The formazan concentration, quantified by color intensity, correlates directly with viable cell numbers. 77 BCM Brassica carinata 18 19 34 21 78 BCM- 50 50 et al 34 Sphaeranthus indicus 79 79 79 BCM 80 The selectivity index (SI) evaluates how selectively a compound exerts cytotoxic effects on cancer cells over normal cells. 81 82 BCM- . This relapse is driven by residual cancer cells that reacquire their malignant properties, including sustained proliferative signaling and resistance to apoptosis. 21 89 BCM BCM 90 91 92 50 BCM et al 21 The cell cycle plays a crucial role in the transition of normal cells into cancer. The different phases (G1, S, G2) control cells' movement through the cycle, ensuring that cells cannot proceed to the next stage if their DNA is damaged. Many cancer drugs exploit this by triggering cell cycle arrest through DNA damage and ultimately blocking tumor progression. 48 93 BCM BCM- 50 25 BCM 50 25 BCM 41 BCM 94 95 96 Many anticancer agents target apoptotic pathways, underscoring the importance of understanding apoptosis in the development of effective cancer treatments.
